/Users/adityagk/Desktop/capstone/iterati.description:
This file serves as the public entry point for the `decorators` module within the TypedActor.js library. Its primary purpose is to aggregate and re-export the `handle` decorator, providing a convenient way for other modules to import all decorators from a single path. This decorator is crucial for enabling type-safe, declarative message handling in actor methods.

Core Components: This file exports the `handle` function, which is a method decorator. The `handle` decorator takes a `MessageType` (a class constructor) as a parameter and returns a `MethodDecorator` used to mark actor methods for specific message processing.

Internal Dependencies: It imports the `handle` function from `./handle-message.ts`, which contains the actual implementation of the decorator.

External Dependencies: There are no explicit third-party library dependencies for this specific file beyond TypeScript's built-in decorator features.

This file serves as a barrel export for the persistence module, consolidating and re-exporting core components related to actor state persistence and event sourcing. Its primary role is to provide a simplified public interface for consuming the persistence features within the TypedActor.js library.

Core Components: It exposes `JournalPlugin` (an abstract interface for persistence backends), `InMemoryJournal` (a concrete in-memory implementation of the journal), and `PersistentActor` (the base class for actors that utilize event sourcing).

Internal Dependencies: This file is coupled with `./journal/journal-plugin`, `./journal/in-memory-journal`, and `./persistent-actor`, from which it re-exports their public APIs.

External Dependencies: This file itself does not introduce any direct external dependencies. Any external dependencies would originate from the modules it re-exports.

This index.ts file serves as the public API entry point for the supervision module of the TypedActor.js library. Its primary role is to re-export the core components related to fault tolerance and actor failure management, providing a unified interface for other parts of the system to access supervision capabilities.

Core Components: This file re-exports `SupervisionStrategy`, an object defining different policies for handling actor failures (e.g., Restart, Resume, Stop, Escalate), and `Supervisor`, a class that encapsulates the logic for applying these strategies based on specific failure conditions. These are crucial for building resilient actor hierarchies.

Internal Dependencies: This file directly depends on and imports from `src/supervision/strategy.ts`, which contains the actual definitions of `SupervisionStrategy` and `Supervisor`.

External Dependencies: This file does not introduce any direct external dependencies. Its functionality relies solely on internal project modules and standard TypeScript features.

The .gitignore file specifies patterns for files and directories that Git should ignore in the TypedActor.js project. It prevents generated files, build artifacts, dependency modules, log files, and IDE configurations from being committed to the repository, maintaining a clean codebase. This file contains a list of exclusion patterns for various types of unwanted files and directories. It has no internal or external code dependencies, as its function is purely for Git version control management.

This file defines the abstract base class `Actor` which all user-defined actors in the TypedActor.js system must extend. It provides fundamental lifecycle hooks such as `preStart`, `postStop`, `preRestart`, and `postRestart`, along with an abstract `receive` method that subclasses implement for handling messages. The primary core component is the `Actor<T>` abstract class, which includes a protected `context` field and the aforementioned lifecycle and message handling methods. This file internally depends on `src/core/actor-context.ts` for the `ActorContext` class and `src/core/actor-ref.ts` for the `ActorRef` class. It has no direct external dependencies.

This file serves as a barrel export for the core module of the TypedActor.js library, consolidating and re-exporting foundational components. It provides a convenient single entry point for accessing the essential building blocks of the actor model. Its primary role is to simplify imports and structure the core API surface for other parts of the system.

Core Components: This file re-exports the Actor class, which defines the abstract base for all actors; ActorSystem, managing actor lifecycles and providing the system's root; ActorRef, an immutable and location-transparent reference for actor communication; and ActorContext, which provides actors with an interface to interact with the system and their children.

Internal Dependencies: The file explicitly re-exports from ./actor-context, ./actor-ref, ./actor-system, and ./actor.

External Dependencies: None. This file serves purely as an internal re-exporter within the project's core module.

This file serves as the main public interface for the cluster-related functionalities within the TypedActor.js library. It consolidates and re-exports essential components for building distributed actor systems, including tools for cluster membership, remote communication, and actor sharding. Its role is to simplify imports for consumers of the cluster module.

Core Components: This file exports the `MembershipProvider` class for managing cluster node discovery, `MemberUp`, `MemberDown`, and `UnreachableMember` classes for cluster event notifications, the `RemoteActorRef` class for interacting with actors on remote nodes, the `Serializer` class for message serialization, and the `ClusterSharding` class for distributing actors across the cluster.

Internal Dependencies: This file imports from and depends on `src/cluster/membership/membership-provider.ts`, `src/cluster/membership/cluster-events.ts`, `src/cluster/remote/remote-actor-ref.ts`, `src/cluster/remote/serialization.ts`, and `src/cluster/sharding/cluster-sharding.ts`.

External Dependencies: None directly, as it only re-exports internal project modules.

The strategy.ts file defines the fundamental concepts for fault tolerance and supervision in the TypedActor.js library. It provides an enumeration of actions to take when an actor fails (Restart, Resume, Stop, Escalate) and a Supervisor class that encapsulates the logic for deciding which action to apply based on an encountered error. This module is crucial for enabling the hierarchical failure management described in the project's supervision feature.
The core components include the exported `SupervisionStrategy` constant object, which defines the four symbolic strategies: Restart, Resume, Stop, and Escalate. Additionally, the `Supervisor` class is exported, which is instantiated with a `decider` function that maps an `Error` to one of the defined `SupervisionStrategy` actions.
This file does not explicitly import any other files from the project or external libraries. However, its exports, particularly the `Supervisor` class and `SupervisionStrategy` type, are implicitly intended to be used by other parts of the actor system, such as parent actors (likely in `src/core/actor.ts` or `src/core/actor-context.ts`) when implementing supervision hierarchies and handling child actor failures.
There are no external dependencies identified in this file.

The mailbox.ts file defines the generic Mailbox<T> class, a fundamental component of the TypedActor.js system. It implements the AsyncIterableIterator interface to provide a non-blocking, backpressure-aware message queue for individual actors. This allows actors to asynchronously consume messages, ensuring efficient and orderly processing.

Core Components: The Mailbox<T> class is the key component, encapsulating a message queue and a mechanism for resolving pending asynchronous requests for messages. Its enqueue method adds messages, while the next method, implementing the AsyncIterableIterator protocol, allows messages to be consumed asynchronously, handling both immediately available messages and future messages via promises. The close method signals the end of the message stream.

Internal Dependencies: This file is a core utility that would be instantiated and utilized by actor.ts to provide each actor with its personal message queue. It is implicitly coupled with the core actor lifecycle and message dispatching mechanisms.

External Dependencies: None. The implementation relies entirely on native TypeScript/JavaScript features like Promises and Async Iterators.

This file serves as the main public API entry point for the TypedActor.js library. It acts as a barrel file, consolidating and re-exporting key classes, decorators, interfaces, and types from various sub-modules to offer a unified import surface for library consumers. Its purpose is to simplify access to the distributed actor system's core functionalities, persistence mechanisms, supervision strategies, and clustering capabilities.

Core components exposed include ActorSystem, Actor, ActorRef, ActorContext, the handle message decorator, PersistentActor, JournalPlugin, SupervisionStrategy, Supervisor, ClusterSharding, MembershipProvider, system messages like PoisonPill and Failure, and the Logger utility.

Internal dependencies are extensive, linking to `src/core/actor-system.ts`, `src/core/actor.ts`, `src/core/actor-ref.ts`, `src/core/actor-context.ts`, `src/decorators/handle-message.ts`, `src/persistence/persistent-actor.ts`, `src/persistence/journal/journal-plugin.ts`, `src/supervision/strategy.ts`, `src/cluster/sharding/cluster-sharding.ts`, `src/cluster/membership/membership-provider.ts`, `src/types/messages.ts`, and `src/utils/logger.ts`.

This file has no direct external library dependencies.

This tsconfig.json file configures the TypeScript compiler for the TypedActor.js project, specifying compilation settings for modern JavaScript targets, module resolution, strict type checking, and decorator support. It defines the source directory as `src/` and the output directory as `dist/`, enabling the generation of declaration files and source maps.

Its core components are the compiler options such as `target: ES2022`, `module: NodeNext`, `strict: true`, `experimentalDecorators: true`, and `emitDecoratorMetadata: true`, which dictate how TypeScript code is transformed into JavaScript. It explicitly includes all `.ts` files within the `src/` directory for compilation.

This configuration implicitly governs the compilation and type-checking rules for all TypeScript source files within the `TypedActor.js` project, ensuring consistency and proper interpretation of language features like decorators.

The file's functionality is entirely dependent on the TypeScript compiler and its standard library definitions, which are external tools and packages used to process the project's source code.

This file serves as the main entry point for the `utils` module, primarily re-exporting common utilities. Its purpose is to consolidate and simplify imports for utility functions and classes provided by the `src/utils` directory. It acts as an aggregation point, making the `Logger` readily available throughout the TypedActor.js project.

Core Components: This file exports the `Logger` utility, which provides basic logging functionalities such as `info`, `warn`, and `error` methods.

Internal Dependencies: It depends on `./logger.ts` for the `Logger` export.

External Dependencies: None apparent in this specific file's content.

This file defines core, system-level message types used across the TypedActor.js library. It provides the PoisonPill message for actor termination and the Failure message for communicating errors within the supervision hierarchy, crucial for managing actor lifecycles and fault tolerance. Core Components: Exports the PoisonPill class, a signal for an actor to stop itself, and the Failure class, which encapsulates an error with a reason property, used for actor supervision. Internal Dependencies: None. This file provides fundamental message definitions consumed by various parts of the actor system, such as actor lifecycle management and supervision logic, rather than depending on them. External Dependencies: None. The file uses only built-in JavaScript types like Error.

The .env.example file serves as a template for environment variables configuring the TypedActor.js system. It defines crucial settings for the actor system's name, enables and configures the distributed cluster's host, port, and seed nodes, specifies event sourcing persistence details such as the journal plugin and storage paths, and sets the application's logging level. This file is fundamental for quickly setting up and deploying a TypedActor.js application, especially for clustered and stateful scenarios.

Core Components: This file defines configuration variables for the `TYPED_ACTOR_SYSTEM_NAME`, `TYPED_ACTOR_CLUSTER_ENABLED`, `TYPED_ACTOR_CLUSTER_HOST`, `TYPED_ACTOR_CLUSTER_PORT`, `TYPED_ACTOR_CLUSTER_SEED_NODES`, `TYPED_ACTOR_PERSISTENCE_JOURNAL_PLUGIN`, `TYPED_ACTOR_PERSISTENCE_DATABASE_URL`, `TYPED_ACTOR_PERSISTENCE_FS_PATH`, and `TYPED_ACTOR_LOG_LEVEL`.

Internal Dependencies: The configuration values defined in this file are intended to be consumed by the ActorSystem initialization (`src/core/actor-system.ts`), cluster management components (`src/cluster/membership/membership-provider.ts`, `src/cluster/sharding/cluster-sharding.ts`), persistence mechanisms (`src/persistence/journal/journal-plugin.ts`, `src/persistence/persistent-actor.ts`), and the logging utility (`src/utils/logger.ts`).

External Dependencies: The application loading this file would typically use a library like `dotenv` to parse these environment variables at runtime.

This file defines the abstract MembershipProvider class, which serves as a foundational interface for managing cluster node discovery and membership within the TypedActor.js distributed system. It outlines core operations like a node joining or leaving a cluster and retrieving a list of active member addresses, enabling various concrete implementations for cluster management. The primary component is the abstract MembershipProvider class, which establishes a contract for cluster membership management. It declares abstract methods: `join(system: ActorSystem)` to initiate membership in the cluster, `leave()` to gracefully exit, and `getMembers()` to retrieve a list of currently active cluster node addresses. This file imports `ActorSystem` from `src/core/actor-system.ts`, which is required for the `join` method. Implementations of MembershipProvider would typically interact closely with `src/cluster/membership/cluster-events.ts` to publish membership changes. None.

This file defines concrete event types that signal changes in the state of members within a distributed actor cluster. It provides `MemberUp`, `MemberDown`, and `UnreachableMember` classes, which are utilized by the cluster membership module to publish topology updates across the actor system. These events facilitate dynamic cluster management and fault detection.

Core Components: Classes: MemberUp (event for a member joining or becoming available), MemberDown (event for a member leaving or being explicitly removed), UnreachableMember (event for a member becoming temporarily unreachable). Each event carries a `memberAddress` (string) to identify the specific node.

Internal Dependencies: While not directly importing, this file implicitly couples with `membership-provider.ts` (which would likely produce these events) and the central `ActorSystem` (which provides the event bus for publishing and subscribing to these events). Other cluster-related modules like `cluster-sharding.ts` and `remote-actor-ref.ts` would consume these events to adapt to topology changes.

External Dependencies: None. The file exclusively uses standard TypeScript/JavaScript language features.

This file provides a basic, timestamped logging utility for the TypedActor.js system. It centralizes common logging operations for informational messages, warnings, and errors, designed for both internal system diagnostics and use within user-defined actors. The `Logger` object is the primary component, offering `info`, `warn`, and `error` methods to output formatted log messages to the console with timestamps. This file does not directly import or depend on other internal files within the TypedActor.js project. The file utilizes built-in JavaScript/TypeScript features such as `Date` and `console` for logging, without relying on any third-party libraries.

This file provides core utilities for serializing and deserializing actor messages, facilitating their transmission across network boundaries in the distributed TypedActor.js system. It enables the conversion of arbitrary JavaScript objects into a binary format (Buffer) suitable for network transport and their reconstruction on the receiving end, ensuring location-transparent communication.
Core Components: The file exports a `Serializer` class which contains two primary methods: `serialize(message: any): Buffer` to convert objects to Buffers, and `deserialize(data: Buffer): any` to convert Buffers back into objects. These methods currently leverage JSON for the conversion process.
Internal Dependencies: This file is a critical component for `src/cluster/remote/remote-actor-ref.ts`, as remote actor references would rely on this serializer to prepare outgoing messages and process incoming ones. It implicitly works with the various message types defined across the actor system.
External Dependencies: It utilizes Node.js/Bun's built-in `Buffer` object for handling binary data and JavaScript's `JSON.stringify` and `JSON.parse` methods for the default serialization implementation.

This file defines the @handle decorator, a core component for type-safe message processing within the TypedActor.js system. It allows developers to declaratively associate specific actor methods with particular message types, facilitating a clean and organized approach to defining actor behavior by storing message-to-method mappings on the actor's prototype. The key components include the handle decorator function and the ACTOR_MESSAGE_HANDLERS Symbol for internal message routing. The file implicitly couples with the core actor definitions and message dispatching logic, likely within actor.ts or mailbox.ts, and defines no direct external dependencies, relying on standard TypeScript and JavaScript features.

The package.json file serves as the manifest for the `typed-actor.js` library, a distributed actor system. It provides essential project metadata such as its name, version, description, and keywords, along with author and licensing details. It also defines crucial scripts for development workflows including starting, building, testing, linting, and formatting the project, and specifies its various internal and external dependencies.

Core components described in this file include the project's identifying metadata, distribution entry points (main, module, types, exports), and a comprehensive set of npm/bun scripts that orchestrate the library's development, build, and publishing processes.

Internal dependencies are implicitly defined through script commands referencing files like `src/index.ts` for execution and building, and `tsconfig.json` for TypeScript compilation. The `dist` directory is also an internal output artifact managed by this file.

External dependencies primarily consist of development tools like `@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin`, `@typescript-eslint/parser`, `eslint`, `prettier`, `typescript`, `@types/bun`, and `@types/node`. The project currently lists no runtime production dependencies.

This file provides an in-memory implementation of the `JournalPlugin` interface, serving as a non-persistent event store for `PersistentActor`s during development or testing. It allows actors to write events to a private map and replay them from a specified sequence number, simulating event sourcing without requiring an external database.

Core Components:
InMemoryJournal class: Implements the JournalPlugin interface, providing methods to store and retrieve events in a simple in-memory Map.
writeEvents method: Appends new events to an array associated with a given persistence ID.
replayEvents method: Returns an async iterable of events for a given persistence ID, starting from a specified sequence number.

Internal Dependencies:
./journal-plugin (JournalPlugin interface)

External Dependencies:
None.

This file defines the ActorContext class, which serves as the primary interface for an actor to interact with its containing actor system. It allows actors to manage their lifecycle by creating child actors, stopping existing children, and accessing references to themselves, their parent, and the overarching actor system.
The ActorContext<T> class is exported, providing `self`, `parent`, and `system` as readonly fields. It includes `spawn` and `stop` methods for child actor management.
It imports ActorRef from `./actor-ref` and ActorSystem, ActorProps from `./actor-system`.
None.

This file, `journal-plugin.ts`, defines the abstract `JournalPlugin` interface, acting as the fundamental contract for all event sourcing persistence backends within the TypedActor.js library. It specifies abstract methods for asynchronously writing new events to a persistent journal and for replaying stored events from a given sequence number, which is critical for the recovery and durability of `PersistentActor` states. The core component is the abstract `JournalPlugin` class, which mandates the `writeEvents` method for appending events and the `replayEvents` method for providing an `AsyncIterable` of past events. Internally, this abstract plugin is implemented by concrete journal storage solutions such as `src/persistence/journal/in-memory-journal.ts` and is utilized by `src/persistence/persistent-actor.ts` for its persistence capabilities. This file has no direct external dependencies.

This file acts as the primary public API entry point for the TypedActor.js library, consolidating essential types, classes, and functions from across its various modules. It simplifies developer interaction by re-exporting core actor system components, cluster utilities, decorators, persistence interfaces, supervision strategies, and logging tools, along with defining the fundamental ActorProps type. Its main role is to provide a convenient, centralized import path for all key building blocks necessary to develop applications with the library.

Key core components exported include Actor, ActorContext, ActorRef, ActorSystem, PersistentActor, JournalPlugin, SupervisionStrategy, Supervisor, handle decorator, ClusterSharding, MembershipProvider, Serializer, and system messages like PoisonPill and Failure. The file internally depends on nearly all other major modules of the TypedActor.js project, including core actor components, cluster management, decorators, persistence, supervision, and utility files. There are no direct external library dependencies for this specific file, as it primarily serves to re-export internal components.

This file defines the abstract PersistentActor class, a cornerstone for implementing stateful actors that leverage event sourcing for durability. It manages the recovery of actor state by replaying historical events from a journal and provides a protected method for persisting new events. Subclasses are responsible for defining their unique persistence ID and specifying how events are applied to reconstruct their in-memory state.

Core Components:
Class: PersistentActor<E, S> (abstract base class for persistent entities).
Abstract field: persistenceId (string, unique identifier for the persistent actor).
Protected field: state (S, the current in-memory state, updated by events).
Protected method: persist(event: E): Promise<void> (writes an event to the journal and applies it).
Abstract method: receiveRecover(event: E): void (logic to apply an event to the actor's state during recovery or persistence).
Method override: preStart(): Promise<void> (initializes persistence by recovering state from the journal).

Internal Dependencies:
src/core/actor: PersistentActor extends the base Actor class.
src/core/actor-context: Used to access the actor's context and system-wide services like the JournalPlugin.
src/persistence/journal/journal-plugin: An interface used to interact with the underlying event journal for reading and writing events.
src/utils/logger: Utilized for logging persistence-related information and errors.

External Dependencies:
None.

This README.md file serves as the primary documentation for the TypedActor.js library, a distributed actor system for TypeScript on Bun/Node.js. It provides an overview of the project, details its core features like type-safe messaging, supervision, event sourcing persistence, and cluster sharding, and offers installation and quick start guides. The file also explains fundamental actor concepts and outlines the project's modular structure.

Its core components include the project overview, a detailed features list, installation instructions and a quick start example with code, explanations of core concepts such as ActorSystem, Actor, ActorRef, ActorContext, Messages, Supervision, Persistence, and Cluster Sharding, and a representation of the project structure. It implicitly references numerous internal files like `src/core/actor-system.ts`, `src/core/actor.ts`, `src/decorators/handle-message.ts`, `src/persistence/persistent-actor.ts`, `src/cluster/sharding/cluster-sharding.ts`, and others to describe the implementation of its core concepts. External dependencies mentioned or implied include package managers like `bun`, `npm`, and `yarn` for installing the `typed-actor` library itself, and runtime environments `Bun` or `Node.js`.

This file defines the core ActorRef abstract class, which serves as an immutable and location-transparent reference to an actor instance within the TypedActor.js system. It establishes the fundamental contract for sending messages to actors, supporting both fire-and-forget (tell) and request-response (ask) communication patterns, and encapsulates the logic for managing ask promises and timeouts.

The core components include the abstract ActorRef<T> class itself, which defines the `tell` and `ask` methods, along with the AskEnvelope and AskReplyEnvelope classes for managing the request-response pattern, and AskTimeoutError for handling timeouts. The ActorPath type alias represents an actor's unique identifier.

Internal dependencies include the `ActorSystem` (from './actor-system') for registering and managing ask promises, and it implicitly couples with concrete implementations of `ActorRef` (like `LocalActorRef` and `RemoteActorRef`) and the `Actor` class that receives messages. External dependencies include the `uuid` library for generating unique correlation IDs for ask messages.

This file defines the RemoteActorRef class, which is a specialized ActorRef for communicating with actors residing on remote nodes within the cluster. It provides location transparency by extending the base ActorRef and implementing network communication logic, including message serialization and delegation of transport to the ActorSystem. It supports both fire-and-forget (tell) and request-response (ask) messaging patterns.

Core Components: The RemoteActorRef<T> class is the primary component, providing public tell and ask methods for sending and receiving messages. It includes a private parseRemoteAddress utility for extracting connection details from a remote actor's address string.

Internal Dependencies: This file imports ActorRef and ActorSystem from '../../core', Serializer from './serialization', and Logger from '../../utils/logger'.

External Dependencies: None.

This file is a core component of the cluster sharding feature, providing the main entry point for users to distribute entity actors across a cluster for horizontal scaling and load balancing. It manages the lifecycle and routing for sharded actors by initializing shard regions and proxies, abstracting the underlying distribution logic.
The `ClusterSharding` class is the primary API, offering a singleton `get` method to access the extension and an `init` method to configure sharding for specific actor types. It internally uses the `ShardingProxyRef` class to route messages to the correct shard, relying on `extractEntityId` and `extractShardId` functions.
Internal dependencies include `ActorSystem`, `ActorRef`, `ActorContext`, and `Actor` from the core actor system, `Logger` for utility logging, and `ShardCoordinator` and `ShardRegion` from the same `sharding` module for orchestrating and managing local actor instances within a shard.
There are no external third-party library dependencies directly imported by this file.

The `actor-system.ts` file defines the core `ActorSystem` class, which serves as the central runtime environment for all actors in the TypedActor.js framework. It is responsible for initializing the system, creating system and user guardian actors, spawning new actors, managing their lifecycle (starting, stopping, restarting), and implementing fault tolerance through supervision strategies. This file provides the primary API for users to interact with and manage the actor hierarchy.

Core Components: The `ActorSystem` class manages an internal registry of `ActorCell` objects, each encapsulating an actor's instance, reference, context, and mailbox. Key methods include `create` (singleton creation), `spawn` (for creating new top-level actors), `internalStop` (for controlled termination), and `terminate` (for system shutdown). It also contains private methods like `runMailbox` to process messages and apply supervision logic, and `createSystemGuardian`/`createRootGuardian` to set up the foundational actor hierarchy.

Internal Dependencies: This file imports `Actor`, `ActorProps`, `ActorConstructor` from `./actor`; `ActorRef` from `./actor-ref`; `ActorContext` from `./actor-context`; `Mailbox` from `./mailbox`; `Logger` from `../utils/logger`; `Supervisor`, `SupervisionStrategy` from `../supervision/strategy`; and `PoisonPill`, `Failure` from `../types/messages`.

External Dependencies: This file primarily relies on standard TypeScript/JavaScript features and the Bun/Node.js runtime environment (e.g., `Promise`, `setTimeout`), without explicit third-party library imports within the provided content.

This file implements the ShardRegion actor, a crucial part of the distributed cluster sharding system. It manages the lifecycle of Shard actors on a local node, acting as a proxy to route messages for specific entities to their corresponding shard or requesting shard allocation from the ShardCoordinator. The file also defines several message types used for internal communication within the sharding mechanism.

Core Components: The ShardRegion class is an Actor responsible for orchestrating shards and entities. It handles messages like ShardRegionRegistered, ShardHomeAllocated, HandOff, and PassivateEntity. It internally spawns and manages Shard actors. The Shard class is an internal Actor that manages the lifecycle of individual entity actors within a specific shard, spawning them on demand and handling their passivation. Several message classes such as ShardEnvelope, RegisterShardRegion, GetShardHome, and PassivateEntity define the communication protocol within the sharding system.

Internal Dependencies: It imports Actor, ActorProps, ActorRef, and ActorContext from the core actor system. The handle decorator from decorators/handle-message is used for declarative message handling. It utilizes the Logger utility for logging and PoisonPill from types/messages for actor termination.

External Dependencies: No explicit third-party library imports are present in this file.

This file defines the ShardCoordinator actor, a central component in the TypedActor.js cluster sharding mechanism. It is a PersistentActor responsible for maintaining the allocation of shards (groups of entities) to ShardRegion actors across the cluster, ensuring even distribution and handling reallocations when cluster members join or leave. It manages shard lifecycle events and provides location transparency for sharded entities.

Core Components: The file exports the ShardCoordinator class, which is a PersistentActor. It defines internal messages (RegisterShardRegion, RequestShardAllocation, ShardAllocated, ShardTerminated) and events (ShardRegionRegisteredEvent, ShardRegionRemovedEvent, ShardAllocatedEvent, ShardTerminatedEvent) for its operation. Key methods include preStart and postStop for lifecycle management, receiveRecover for state recovery, and message handlers like onRegisterShardRegion, onRequestShardAllocation, and onShardTerminated, alongside handlers for cluster membership events (onMemberUp, onMemberDown, onUnreachableMember). The state is managed through the ShardCoordinatorState interface.

Internal Dependencies: This file imports Actor, ActorContext, ActorRef from `core/actor`, the handle decorator from `decorators/handle-message`, PersistentActor from `persistence/persistent-actor`, Logger from `utils/logger`, ActorSystem from `core/actor-system`, and MemberUp, MemberDown, UnreachableMember from `cluster/membership/cluster-events`. It conceptually couples with `shard-region.ts` by defining the messages exchanged between them.

External Dependencies: None.
